data.title: George Orwell (Writer)

data.text:
George Orwell

Full Name: Eric Arthur Blair

Profession: Writer

Biography: Born in imperial India and educated at Eton, Orwell was a colonial policeman in Burma and fought against the fascists in the Spanish civil war.

His most famous works are "The Road to Wigan Pier", "Animal Farm" and "Nineteen Eighty-Four".

Born: June 25, 1903

Birthplace: Motihari, Bengal, British India

Generation: Greatest Generation

Chinese Zodiac: Rabbit

Star Sign: Cancer

Died: January 21, 1950 (aged 46)

Cause of Death: Burst pulmonary artery

Articles and Photos

Grim History of London's Speakers' Corner

Nowhere in England is the principal of free speech embodied more than at Speakers’ Corner in London’s Hyde Park. But this right was won through death and protest.

Writer Becomes a Prisoner of Love

In his youth novelist George Gissing sparkled with literary and academic promise. But his choice of female partners led to anguish, poverty and even prison.

Nineteen Eighty-Four Published

The cover of the first edition of George Orwell's classic novel

Married Life

Novelist and journalist George Orwell (33) weds Eileen Maud O'Shaugnessy (30) at St. Mary's Church

Historical Events

George Orwell publishes "Animal Farm" in the United Kingdom

Secker & Warburg publishes George Orwell's seminal novel "Nineteen Eighty-Four", set in the totalitarian state of Oceania

Author of "Brave New World" Aldous Huxley writes to congratulate George Orwell on his new novel "Nineteen Eighty-Four"

Apple's seminal ad for the new Microsoft computer, directed by Ridley Scott, loosely based on George Orwell's "1984", plays during the Super Bowl

Winston Smith in Orwell's novel "Nineteen Eighty-Four" begins his secret diary in defiance of the totalitarian government of Oceania

Quotes by George Orwell

"Within any important issue, there are always aspects no one wishes to discuss."

Biographies and Sources

40 Years Ago, This Ad Changed the Super Bowl Forever - The New York Times
